questions.text: What is the lifespan of a platelet?
questions.solution:
The average lifespan of platelets in circulation is 7–10 days.

Thrombopoietin (TPO) is the regulator of platelet production. A reduction in platelet and megakaryocyte mass increases the level of TPO, which then stimulates platelet production.

The shelf life of donor platelets is 5 days. It is stored on a special agitator at 20-24 °C. The half-life of transfused platelets is 3-5 days.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in patients with a platelet disorder?
questions.solution:
Hemarthrosis is highly suggestive of a coagulation disorder, not a platelet disorder.

Bleeding diathesis can occur due to:

  • Platelet disorders - mucocutaneous bleeding like petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, epistaxis, menorrhagia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds
  • Coagulation disorders - hemarthrosis, muscle hematomas, and bleeding into soft tissues
  • Disorders of the vessel wall (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, scurvy) - purpura and ecchymosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a disorder of platelet adhesion?
questions.solution: Bernard Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. It occurs due to an inherited defect in the GPIb-IX complex.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions would have a low platelet count?
questions.solution:
Thrombocytopenia is a feature of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

It is an X-linked recessive condition caused by mutations in the WASP gene. It affects T-cells and platelets and presents with the following features: 

  • Eczema
  • Thrombocytopenia - along with decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response
  • Immunodeficiency - low IgM, high IgE, defective regulatory T cells causing recurrent bacterial infections.

Option A: Platelet storage pool disorder is a disorder of defective platelet granule formation.

Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a type of small vessel vasculitis in children and young adults.

Option D: Hemophilia is a coagulation disorder, hence the platelet count is not affected.

questions.text: Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Common drugs that cause this are quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds. 

Drug-dependent antibody binding can only be demonstrated in the presence of the drug in the laboratory assays. The thrombocytopenia normally occurs within 21 days of initial exposure and usually gets resolved after 7-10 days once the drug is stopped. 

Immune-mediated destruction of platelets is seen in:

  • Drug-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Infection-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Idiopathic/ immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Option A: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet adhesion. There are no autoantibodies against platelets.

Option B: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is an inherited disorder with defective granule formation in platelets. It affects platelet activation and aggregation.

Option C: Thrombotic microangiopathies like thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) lead to thrombocytopenia due to increased platelet consumption.

questions.text: A young man comes to you with complaints of bleeding gums and the following skin rash. He reports that he had diarrhea last week after eating at a roadside eatery. History is significant for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago that was treated with heparin. His CBC report revealed a platelet count of 15,000/µL, normal RBC and WBC count. His peripheral smear was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing petechiae are suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder with autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C.

It presents with features of mucocutaneous bleeding. CBC shows isolated thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear does not reveal any hemolysis. 

Acute ITP Chronic ITP
Common in children Common in adults (females > males)
Associated with an antecedent viral infection Not associated with antecedent infection
Spontaneous remission in 80% cases Spontaneous remission is not usually seen

Options A and B: HUS and TTP are microangiopathies. They are associated with hemolysis and schistocytes on peripheral smear. 

Option D: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia typically presents within 5-10 days of treatment. Hence, it is not the likely diagnosis in this patient.

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body. Abdominal examination revealed no hepatosplenomegaly. The platelet count is 15,000/µL and the coagulation profile is normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
This scenario is suggestive of acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is seen in coagulation disorders and is not a manifestation of this condition.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)  is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic.

Acute ITP is common in children and is usually preceded by viral infection. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding (epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis). Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent. The following laboratory features are seen:

  • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
  • Bleeding time - prolonged
  • PT/aPTT/INR - normal
  • Bone marrow - normal/increased megakaryocytes
  • Peripheral smear - normal

This condition resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases. Treatment is as follows:

  • Platelet count < 30,000 with risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders): Oral glucocorticoids or IVIG 
  • Severe bleeding symptoms: IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG 
  • Life-threatening bleeding (like intracranial hemorrhage): platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the ER after developing a spontaneous nosebleed. Over the past 1 week, she has noticed blood on her toothbrush while brushing her teeth. She was diagnosed with hepatitis C three months ago. Investigations reveal a platelet count of 32,000/ µL and a bleeding time of 9 minutes . Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: She requires regular platelet transfusions until platelet count is normalized
Prednisone  or anti-D immunoglobulins can be used as the first-line treatment
Splenectomy may be done if she relapses after medical management
Romiplostim and eltrombopag can be used if there is no response to splenectomy

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in an adult patient is suggestive of chronic ITP (idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura). She does not require platelet transfusion. It is recommended only for patients with severe bleeding manifestations (intracranial/ gastrointestinal) or platelet count < 5000 μL.

Chronic ITP can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. Depending on the clinical features, the management is as follows:

  Clinical features Management

1.   

Minor bleeding manifestations (and/or)

Platelet count > 5000/ μL

Prednisone (OR)

Anti-D immunoglobulin therapy - effective only in Rh-positive patients (OR)

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

2.  

Severe ITP (any of the following):

  • Significant GI / intracranial bleeding
  • Platelet count < 5000/μL
  • Signs of impending bleeding (retinal or large oral mucosal bleeds)

Platelet transfusion (AND)

High-dose glucocorticoids (AND)

IVIG / Anti-D immunoglobulins + Rituximab
3.   Relapse after first-line therapy Splenectomy
4.    Unresponsive to all other therapy or relapse after splenectomy Thrombopoietin receptor agonists - romiplostim (subcutaneous), eltrombopag (oral)

questions.text: Which of the following is the best treatment for the relapse of immune thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Splenectomy is the treatment of choice in a case of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) relapse after first line therapy with glucocorticoids. The relapse usually occurs once they are tapered. Vaccination against encapsulated organisms (pneumococcus, meningococcus, H. influenzae) is advised before splenectomy is performed.

It is important to note that in some patients ITP resolves by itself, and observation along with intermittent IV immunoglobulins and anti - Rh(D) administration or administration of a thrombopoietin receptor agonist (eltrombopag, romiplostim) can be a viable option before splenectomy is considered.

The treatment of ITP is as follows:

  Clinical features Management

1.   

Minor bleeding manifestations (and/or)

Platelet count > 5000/ μL

Prednisone (OR)

Anti-D immunoglobulin therapy - effective only in Rh-positive patients (OR)

Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)

2.  

Severe ITP (any of the following):

  • Significant GI / intracranial bleeding
  • Platelet count < 5000/μL
  • Signs of impending bleeding (retinal or large oral mucosal bleeds)

Platelet transfusion (AND)

High-dose glucocorticoids (AND)

IVIG / Anti-D immunoglobulins + Rituximab
3.   Relapse after first-line therapy Splenectomy
4.    Unresponsive to all other therapy or relapse after splenectomy Thrombopoietin receptor agonists - romiplostim (subcutaneous), eltrombopag (oral)

ITP is an acquired disorder characterized by the immune-mediated destruction of platelets and possibly inhibition of platelet release from the megakaryocyte. Secondary causes of ITP include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), HIV-AIDS, and Hepatitis C.

ITP usually presents with mucocutaneous bleeding, very low platelet count, and normal peripheral blood cells. Patients typically exhibit ecchymoses and petechiae or they may incidentally discover thrombocytopenia during a routine complete blood count. Rarely, life-threatening bleeding may occur. The presence of wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth) and retinal hemorrhages can serve as warning signs of potentially life-threatening bleeding.

questions.text: It is your first day as an intern in the medicine ward. The senior resident tells you to check the platelet count of a patient who is being monitored for thrombocytopenia. He was started on a new medication the previous night. What drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Abciximab can cause a drop in platelet count within 24 hours of initial exposure. Hence, these patients must be monitored for thrombocytopenia. This is due to naturally-occurring antibodies that cross-react with the drug bound to the platelets.

Thrombocytopenia due to other drugs typically occurs several days after exposure (average 21 days) and resolves in 7-10 days after drug withdrawal.  Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can occur due to the following mechanisms:

  • Bone marrow suppression - chemotherapeutic drugs
  • Drug dependent antibodies that react with platelet surface antigens - quinine and sulfonamides
  • Naturally occurring antibodies that cross-react with drugs bound to the platelets - platelet Gp IIb/IIIa inhibitors

Some of the drugs that cause thrombocytopenia are:

  • Antibiotics - ampicillin, cephalosporins, piperacillin, vancomycine
  • Analgesics - ibuprofen, acetaminophen
  • Anti-epileptics - phenytoin, carbamazepine
  • Heparin
  • Amiodarone

questions.text: Patients with all of the following usually present with bleeding except:
questions.solution:
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.

This condition occurs due to the production of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex (platelet factor 4, a platelet-specific protein). These antibodies can activate platelets and result in thrombosis. It is seen 5-14 days after exposure to heparin.

These antibodies can be detected using ELISA or serotonin release assay. This condition is managed by discontinuing heparin and using alternative anticoagulants.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used in the treatment of patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin cannot be used in the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This is because HIT antibodies (against anti-PF4-heparin complex) may cross-react with LMWH.

HIT can occur following exposure to unfractionated heparin and less commonly with LMWH.

The treatment of HIT is as follows:

  • Discontinue heparin
  • Anticoagulation with non-heparin anticoagulants even in the absence of thrombosis, since there is a high risk of thrombosis.
    • Direct thrombin inhibitors: Argatroban, lepirudin, bivalirudin
    • Danaparoid (heparinoid)

questions.text: The CBC of a 33-year-old woman revealed a low platelet count. However, further evaluation revealed this to be an in vitro sampling error. Which of the following is the likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
This scenario is suggestive of pseudothrombocytopenia. It is seen in blood samples collected with EDTA as the anticoagulant.

EDTA causes a reduction in the calcium content of the collected blood sample. This triggers in vitro platelet clumping and agglutination by antibodies (usually IgG), as shown below:

When a low platelet count is obtained with an EDTA sample, the peripheral blood smear should be evaluated. The platelet count must also be determined in blood collected in sodium citrate or heparin collection tubes or fresh fingerstick blood sample.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding patients with Bernard-Soulier syndrome?

choices.text: Platelet aggregation tests with epinephrine and ADP are normal

questions.solution:
The ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal (no aggregation) in patients with Bernard-Soulier (BS) syndrome.

It is an inherited disorder of platelet function or qualitative platelet disorder due to deficiency of the Gp Ib-IX receptor. This is the platelet membrane receptor for the von Willebrand factor (vWF). The binding of the vWF to the GpIb-IX-V complex on the platelet membrane is essential for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall.

This condition presents with mild thrombocytopenia and peripheral smear shows large platelets.

Platelet aggregation tests are performed to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro. Various platelet agonists like ADP, epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin can be used to perform these tests. In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the following responses are seen:

  • With ristocetin - No response/no aggregation, as ristocetin specifically binds to the platelet membrane via the Gp Ib-IXa receptor
  • With ADP or epinephrine - Normal response, as Gp IIb-IIIa receptor is not involved in this process

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common inherited bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

vWD occurs due to deficient or abnormal von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is synthesized by endothelial cells and megakaryocytes (gene located on chromosome 12p). It is then stored in endothelial storage vesicles, Weibel-Palade bodies. Metalloprotease ADAMTS13 cleaves ultra-large multimers of VWF which are responsible for platelet adhesion.

The functions of vWF and the corresponding symptoms include:

  • Adhesion of the platelets to the exposed subendothelium - symptoms of both platelet and bleeding disorders
  • Prolongs the half-life of factor VIII by binding to it in circulation - hemophilia A like symptoms (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following is called autosomal hemophilia?
questions.solution:
Autosomal hemophilia is also called type 2N von Willebrand disease (vWD), as the clinical presentation is similar to hemophilia.

The types of vWD are:

Type Inheritance Mechanism Important characteristics
1 AD Partial quantitative deficiency of VWF Most common type
3 AR Complete quantitative deficiency Most severe VWD
2A AD Loss of VWF multimers (increased cleavage by ADAMS13) Platelet adhesion defect
2B AD Increased binding of VWF to platelets causing VWF-platelet complex destruction Thrombocytopenia
2M AD Decreased affinity of VWF to platelets Platelet adhesion defect, very rare
2N AR Decreased affinity of VWF to Factor VIII Autosomal hemophilia

In pseudo vWD, the vWF is normal. However, platelets have an increased affinity for vWF. It presents similar to vWD 2B with thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following patients has Heyde's syndrome?

choices.text: A man with aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding
A woman with aortic stenosis with intracranial bleed
A man with aortic regurgitation with gastrointestinal bleeding
A woman with aortic regurgitation with intracranial bleed

questions.solution:
Heyde’s syndrome is aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding, due to angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract.

The shear stress on blood passing through the stenotic aortic valve produces a change in the von Willebrand factor making it susceptible to serum proteases. Hence, large multimer forms are lost, leading to an acquired type 2 von Willebrand disease (vWD). The condition is reversed with the replacement of the aortic valve.

Other causes of acquired vWD include:

  • Multiple myeloma
  • Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Polycythemia vera
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings is seen in a patient with von Willebrand's disease?
questions.solution:
Bleeding time is increased in von Willebrand disease (vWD). It is a combination of a platelet adhesion defect with factor VIII deficiency.

The laboratory findings in vWD include: 

  • Platelet count is normal (except type 2B)
  • Bleeding time is prolonged 
  • Ristocetin aggregation is abnormal
  • Other platelet aggregation tests are normal
  • Prothrombin time (PT) is normal
  • aPTT is prolonged
  • VWF activity is decreased
  • Factor VIII activity is decreased

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is being evaluated for prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction. She also reports heavy bleeding during menses and recurrent gum bleeds. Labs show increased aPTT, normal PT, and increased bleeding time. Which of the following is the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand's disease. The preferred first-line treatment is desmopressin (DDAVP).

This drug acts on endothelial V2 receptors causing the release of VWF and factor VIII from endothelial stores. DDAVP can be given intravenously or by an intranasal spray. The side effects include tachyphylaxis and hyponatremia. 

VWF concentrate and factor VIII concentrate are reserved for patients with severe disease or prior to major procedures. Antifibrinolytic therapy (tranexamic acid or ε-aminocaproic acid) may be used for the prevention and treatment of mucosal bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not seen in patients with Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia?

choices.text: Abnormal platelet aggregation on adding ADP

questions.solution:
Thrombocytopenia is not seen in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is a primary defect of platelet function (aggregation). It occurs due to congenital absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. It presents as superficial mucocutaneous bleeding with normal platelet count and single isolated platelets without clumping on peripheral smear. The levels of vWF are normal.

Normally, release of ADP causes platelets to change shape and bind to fibrinogen through the GpIIb/IIIa receptor. In Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, absence of the receptor causes abnormal aggregation (absent or reduced) on adding ADP. However, aggregation in response to ristocetin is normal, as it is dependent on GpIb and vWF.

Secondary platelet dysfunction can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Uremia
  • Paraproteinemia
  • Myeloproliferative disorders

questions.text: A physician decides to start a patient with stroke on antiplatelet medication. All of the following drugs would be effective except:
questions.solution:
Pagoclone is an anxiolytic medication. It is not an antiplatelet drug.

The thienopyridine drugs are ADP receptor or P2Y12 antagonists that inhibit ADP mediated platelet aggregation. They include the following drugs:

  • Clopidogrel - commonly used
  • Ticagrelor - reversible drug with a shorter t1/2, does not require activation, may cause mild, self-limited dyspnea 
  • Prasugrel - 10 times more potent than clopidogrel, rapid onset of action, better absorption, more predictable 
  • Ticlopidine

Clopidogrel and prasugrel are prodrugs that require activation by cytochrome P450 enzymes. CYP2C19 polymorphisms can cause reduced platelet inhibition with clopidogrel and increased risk of cardiovascular events.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman underwent evaluation for bleeding manifestations and severe anemia. Investigations revealed combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Combined autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is called Evans syndrome.

Options B and C: May-Hegglin anomaly and Fechtner syndrome are autosomal dominant hereditary conditions presenting with bleeding, sensorineural hearing loss, glomerulonephritis, and/or eye abnormalities. The severity of the bleeding symptoms is out of proportion to the moderately decreased platelet count.

Option D: Rosenthal syndrome or hemophilia C refers to factor XI deficiency.

questions.text: What is the most common side effect experienced by patients taking enteric-coated aspirin?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of aspirin is gastrointestinal symptoms. The use of enteric-coated aspirin does not reduce these side effects.

Aspirin irreversibly acetylates and inhibits platelet cyclooxygenase (COX)-1, which causes reduced synthesis of thromboxane A2. At high doses, it also inhibits COX-2, which results in the anti-inflammatory effects of aspirin.

The major GI side effects include dyspepsia, erosive gastritis, peptic ulcers with bleeding and perforation. The overall risk of major bleeding with aspirin is 1–3% per year, which increases 2-3 fold if there is concurrent use of other antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by eradication of Helicobacter pylori infection and giving proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

Aspirin sensitivity refers to bronchospasm or urticaria/angioedema seen immediately after administration of aspirin. It is also called Samter's triad (asthma, recurrent nasal polyps, aspirin sensitivity). In patients with aspirin resistance, there is failure of aspirin to produce its normal platelet inhibitory functions.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the mechanism of action of dipyridamole?

choices.text: Increases levels of cyclic AMP in platelets

questions.solution:
Dipyridamole increases extracellular adenosine levels.

It is an antiplatelet drug that increases levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets by:

  • Blocking the reuptake of adenosine and increasing extracellular adenosine levels
  • Inhibiting phosphodiesterase-mediated cAMP degradation

This increase in cyclic AMP reduces intracellular levels of calcium. This inhibits platelet activation and aggregation.

Dipyridamole is a weak antiplatelet used in combination with aspirin for the prevention of stroke in patients with TIA.

Side effects include gastrointestinal and vasodilatory complaints (headache, flushing, dizziness, hypotension). Due to it's vasodilatory effects, it is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man diagnosed with myocardial infarction is planned for percutaneous intervention. He was diagnosed with diabetic nephropathy 2 months ago. The cardiologist decides to start him on aspirin and an additional antiplatelet drug. Which of the following can be used for this patient?
questions.solution:
Abciximab is safe in patients with renal impairment. It belongs to the group of GpIIb-IIIa receptor antagonists. These are parenteral drugs that are used in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome.

There are three important drugs in this group:

questions.text: Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of treatment in patients with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Plasmapheresis is the mainstay of the treatment of patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

The best response to this therapy is seen in patients with ADAMTS13 autoantibodies. Plasmapheresis is continued until the resolution of platelet count and signs of hemolysis for at least 2 days.

Option A: The first line of treatment of autoimmune hemolytic anemia is glucocorticoids. The second line includes rituximab and splenectomy.

Option B: Treatment of disseminated intravascular coagulation is primarily supportive with measures to treat the underlying cause.

Option D: Treatment of HUS is primarily supportive. Dialysis is usually required. In some varients of HUS plasma infusion/exchange can be effective by replasing the complement-regulatory proteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Large vessel arterial or venous thromboemboli are not seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). This condition is associated with microvascular thrombosis.

TTP occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. In this condition, the vWF molecules persist causing pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites.

It presents with the following pentad of clinical features:

  1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - mechanical shearing of RBCs as they pass through platelet rich-microthrombi
  2. Thrombocytopenia - deposition of platelets in microthrombi
  3. Renal failure - microthrombi in the renal vasculature
  4. Neurologic findings - headache, confusion, transient focal neurologic deficits
  5. Fever

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura?

choices.text: Clinical features overlap with hemolytic uremic syndrome
It is common in patients with HIV infection
It can be associated with use of quinine

questions.solution:
In patients with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), the PT and aPTT are normal, as consumptive coagulopathy is not seen.

TTP and HUS are thrombotic microangiopathies with overlapping clinical features. TTP can be primary (ADAMTS13 deficiency) or secondary (associated with infections like HIV and drugs like quinine).

Note: In disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombocytopenia and microangiopathy are seen. It is associated with consumption of clotting factors and fibrinogen resulting in prolonged PT and aPTT.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic abnormality seen in patients with recurrent history of venous thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of venous thrombosis. Venous thrombosis typically manifests as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary thromboembolism. 

Hypercoagulable states or thrombophilias can be inherited or acquired:

  • Inherited causes in decreasing order of prevalence are as follows:
    • Factor V Leiden mutation
    • Prothrombin mutation
    • Protein C deficiency
    • Protein S deficiency
    • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Acquired causes include:
    • Surgery
    • Malignancy
    • Antiphospholipid syndrome
    • Trauma
    • Pregnancy
    • Long-haul travel
    • Obesity
    • Oral contraceptives/hormone replacement
    • Myeloproliferative disorders
    • Polycythemia vera

questions.text: Which of the following qualitative platelet disorders are inherited as autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Platelet storage pool disease (SPD) is an example of an autosomal dominant qualitative platelet disorder. It refers to a group of disorders characterized by a deficiency of platelet granules causing secretion defects.

Bernard Soulier syndrome, Glanzman thrombasthenia, and Chediak-Higashi syndrome are inherited as autosomal recessive traits.
